title: Future not Iterator. Diagnostic could say: FuturesExt needed

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
(1.53 nightly 2021-04-04 )

Given the following code: 
(futures_timer isn't on playground :-( )

```rust
use std::time::Duration;
use futures_timer::Delay;
//Uncomment to make compile:
//use futures::FutureExt;

 fn main() {
    let d  = Delay::new(Duration::from_secs(3));
    let df = d.fuse();
 }
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0599]: the method `fuse` exists for struct `Delay`, but its trait bounds were not satisfied
  --> src/main.rs:8:16
   |
8 |     let df = d.fuse();
   |                ^^^^ method cannot be called on `Delay` due to unsatisfied trait bounds
   | 
  ::: /snip/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/futures-timer-3.0.2/src/native/delay.rs:26:1
   |
26 | pub struct Delay {
   | ---------------- doesn't satisfy `Delay: Iterator`
   |
   = note: the following trait bounds were not satisfied:
           `Delay: Iterator`
           which is required by `&mut Delay: Iterator`
```

I struggled with this and other compiler output suggested adding Pin and Box which as it turned out wasn't helpful.
(In particular it would suggest adding `Pin<Box<>>` , I did that and then it was suggesting `Pin<Box<Pin<Box<>>>>` - you can never have too many pinned boxes :-P )

Ideally a hint about making futures iterable by importing FuturesExt would have shortcutted a lot of head scratching:

```
Did you know Futures can be Iterable if you import FuturesExt?
```

Big kudos to some of the other targetted diagnostics that helped me out when I got into other problems.
